assigmentName: In-Class Test \ Derivatives and Alternative Investment

response.value:
A short position is taken by the trader in a 1-year forward contract.
The shares would be sold by the trader after 1-year at $125.
Fair Forward price = Current price*(1+r)^n
                              = $100*1.06 = $106
However, the actual forward price is $125 which means the forward price is overvalued.
Therefore, arbitrage profit can be earned by the trader.
$100 will be borrowed now at a 6% market price by the trader. 
After 1 year, Trader will sell shares at $125, receive a coupon of $8 and repay a loan of $106.
Therefore, arbitrage profit earned = $125+$8-$106= $27

data.stimulus: A trader takes a short position in a one year forward contract on a 31-year Treasury Bond. The Treasury Bond to be delivered in 1-year is assumed to have an 8% coupon rate and a par value of 100. Using a flat term structure with continuously compounded annual return of 6%. Construct a strategy from which an investor can earn a riskless profit. Assume the 1-year forward price on the bond is $125

metadata.sample_answer:
The spot price at the time the contract is entered is the spot price of a 31-year bond:

\(S_0=100e^{-31\times0.06}+4\times\left(\frac{1-e^{-31\times0.06}}{e^{\frac{0.06}{2}}-1}\right)=126.46\)

The no arbitrage 1-year forward price is 

\(\left(S_{0\ }-I\right)e^r=\left(126.46-4e^{-0.03}-4e^{-0.06}\right)e^{0.06}=126.15\)

The forward price is below the no arbitrage forward price, arrange to buy in one year at the lower price. The strategy is as follows:

  1. Take a long position in a one year forward contract on the bond
  2. Sell short a 31-year 8% T-Bond, receive 126.46
  3. Invest 126.46 for one year at risk free rate
  4. At \(t=0.05\) borrow 4 for 6 months at risk free rate, and pay coupon to person to which the bond was sold.
  5. At time \(t=1\), receive \(126.46e^{0.06}=134.28\) from 1 year investment, pay coupon of 4 and 6-month loan amount of \(4e^{0.03}=4.12\), and close forward contract by buying 30-year T-Bond for 125 and delivering to the party to who it was sold short one year ago; this leaves a riskless profit of \(134.28-4-4.12-125;=1.16\). The riskless profit is the difference between the no arbitrage forward price and the actual forward price as of time 0.

response.value:
​Step 1: Calculate the spot price at the time the contract is entered. This will be the spot price of a 31-year bond
Step 2: Calculate the no arbitrage 1-year forward price
The forward price is below the no arbitrage forward price, so we arrange to buy in one year at the lower price. The strategy is as follows:
1. Take a long position in a one year forward contract on the bond
2. Sell short a 31-year 8% T-Bond, receive 126.46
3. Invest 126.46 for one year at risk free rate
4. At t=0.5 borrow 4 for 6 months at risk free rate, and pay coupon to person to which the bond was sold.
5. At time t=1, receive from 1 year investment, pay coupon of 4 and 6-month loan amount and close forward contract by buying 31-year T-Bond for 125 and delivering to the party to who it was sold short one year ago; this leaves a riskless profit of 1.16. The riskless profit is the difference between the no arbitrage forward price and the actual forward price as of time 0.

data.stimulus: Restrictive covenants can
Coupon bond yields and forward interest rates can be observed directly from market transactions.
The coupon rate is the rate of interest that the investors require, which can be different from the periodic interest payment made by the bond issuer, often called the coupon payment.
The current yield on a bond is a good approximation of the bond's yield to maturity when the bond matures in five years or less and its price differs from its par value by a large amount.
Fixed-income classifications by type of issuer include corporate, and government, and structured finance instruments.
Many jurisdictions periodically tax interest income during the bond lifetime, although the holder of the bond does not receive any cash until maturity.

data.stimulus: Arbitrage opportunities are likely to be exploited except when:

options.label: When associated transaction costs are low.

data.stimulus: Under which of the following conditions will an arbitrageur certainly execute a trade?
Futures contract prices are most likely ___________ when interest rates are constant

response.value: An arbitrageur buys an asset, shorts a futures contract, and makes a delivery for an instant profit if the futures price is higher than the spot price during the delivery period. There is no perfect arbitrage method if the futures price is less than the spot price during the delivery period. An arbitrageur can take a long futures position, but he or she cannot force the item to be delivered immediately. The party with the short position makes the decision on when delivery will take place. Companies interested in acquiring the item, however, will find it more appealing to invest in a long futures contract and wait for delivery.

data.stimulus: Critically explain why an arbitrage opportunity exists when the spot price during delivery period is smaller than the futures price of a commodity. Explain whether there will be arbitrage when the spot price is greater than the futures price?

metadata.sample_answer: If the futures price is greater than the spot price during the delivery period, an arbitrageur buys the asset, shorts a futures contract, and makes delivery for an immediate profit. If the futures price is less than the spot price during the delivery period, there is no similar perfect arbitrage strategy. An arbitrageur can take a long futures position but cannot force immediate delivery of the asset. The decision on when delivery will be made is made by the party with the short position. Nevertheless, companies interested in acquiring the asset may find it attractive to enter into a long futures contract and wait for delivery to be made.

response.value: If the futures price is greater than the spot price during the delivery period, an arbitrageur buys the asset, shorts a futures contract, and makes delivery for an immediate profit. If the futures price is less than the spot price during the delivery period, there is no similar perfect arbitrage strategy. An arbitrageur can take a long futures position but cannot force immediate delivery of the asset. The decision on when delivery will be made is made by the party with the short position. Nevertheless, companies interested in acquiring the asset may find it attractive to enter into a long futures contract and wait for delivery to be made.

data.stimulus: At expiration, the value of the forward contract is:

response.value: Put-call parity only applies to European options that can only be executed on the expiration date, not to American options that may be exercised at any time. Put-call parity says that owning a short European put and a long European call of the same class at the same time would yield the same return as holding a single forward contract on the same underlying asset, with the same expiration and a forward price equal to the option's strike price. If the prices of put and call options diverge to the point where this relationship no longer holds. the trader will have a risk-free profit opportunity. Market seldom provides such chances.

data.stimulus: On June 2, 2018 an investor simultaneously took long positions in a forward contact and a European put option both on the same underlying asset. The maturity of the options contract is the same as that of the forward contract. Describe the profit from the investor's portfolio if the forward price is equal to the strike price.

metadata.sample_answer:
The terminal value of the long forward contract is

 \(S_{T\ }-F_0\)

where \(S_T\) is the price of the asset at maturity and \(F_0\) is the delivery price, which is the same as the forward price of the asset at the time the portfolio is set up. The terminal value of the put option is:

 \(\max\left(F_{0\ }-S_T,\ 0\right)\)

The terminal value of the portfolio is therefore

 \(S_{T\ }-F_0\ +\max\left(F_0\ -S_T,\ 0\right)\)

\(=\max\left(0,\ S_{T\ }-\ F_0\right)\)

This is the same as the terminal value of a European call option with the same maturity as the forward contract and a strike price equal to \(F_0\)

response.value: First determine the terminal value of the long forward, using the asset price at maturity and the delivery price. Second, determine the terminal value of the put option contract. Finally, the payoff of the portfolio is the sum of the terminal P/L of the long forward and the European put. This is the same as the terminal value of a European call option with the same maturity as the forward contract and a strike price equal to delivery price.
